data.title: Woman from Vietnam comes to Lubbock to learn details about her father, how he was killed
data.meta_description: Seven precious letters were all Dao Thi Minh Van had left of her father after the bombing finally stopped. \n The dozens of other messages from him had burned, just more victims of the Hanoi air raidsâ€¦
data.text:
Seven precious letters were all Dao Thi Minh Van had left of her father after the bombing finally stopped.

The dozens of other messages from him had burned, just more victims of the Hanoi air raids.

In them, her father wrote of reunion and a better life for them both - together in times of peace.

He once starting asking her to describe how beautiful she had become, but he caught himself as he wrote.

No, the letter read, words would not do. He wanted to see for himself during the reunion.

It never came.

Hoang Minh Dao instead found three patrol boats, three helicopters and an American ambush.

After surviving two decades of war - first against the French and then against the United States - Hoang Minh Dao died in December 1969 as he crossed the Vam Co Dong River en route to a meeting with other top Communist Party operatives.

He was 46 years old.

Minh Van was barely a toddler in 1946 when her father left to fight the French occupation. His farewell came just a few days after malaria killed her mother.

She doesn't remember the 100-kilometer journey from the village where she was born to North Vietnam's capital city. It took her a year to reach Hanoi, where her new foster family awaited.

They later told her she made the journey in a bucket-like satchel carried by an envoy appointed by her father.

When she arrived, her new foster parents told Minh Van her father left to become a taxi driver in Cambodia.

The letters came only when the couriers made it through American security across the lines. Some were several pages long. Others were hastily scribbled notes.

He never wrote about where he was, Minh Van said. That might have betrayed his top-secret role as a high-ranking spy working in enemy territory.

"He wrote that he was trying to do his best so they could have a reunion," Minh Van said Thursday through a translator. "He was working so she could have beautiful clothes."

As a teenager, she began piecing it together through overheard conversations and rumors.

News of his death took years to find her as an adult with a child of her own.

Once it did, she was not satisfied.

"When my children grew up, they kept asking," she said. "These questions, these lagging questions keep pushing me that I have to find out about my father."

Her quest has taken years. She's pieced much of it together from roughly 400 interviews with aging men who fought with her dad.

They needed time to remember, she said. Some were also wary of all the questions.

So she return to them again and again to earn their trust, to prove that she simply wanted to know what had happened.

No motives. No political agenda. Just a glimpse at a major piece of her own identity.

Her father's peers slowly revealed to her a tale of a man with a warrior's dedication. He had worked in a number of capacities in and around Cu Chi and Saigon - the South Vietnamese capital - performing a variety duties before taking a post as the director of spying operations in the area.

At the time of his death in 1969, between 40,000 and 50,000 North Vietnamese political operatives were working to undermine the enemy on its own turf. Steve Maxner, director of Tech's Vietnam Center and Archive, said the threat of death or capture accompanied the spy chief wherever he went.

"He was running all of the significant operations around Saigon," Maxner said. "That was a tough area to work in. A tough area to stay alive in."

Despite all the interviews and a steady trickle of second-hand accounts of her father, Minh Van has yet to fill in the remaining gaps.

That's why she's been in Lubbock for the past week, working with Maxner at the archives.

Now a successful businesswoman who travels to the United States frequently on business, Minh Van heard about the center from a reporter at a newspaper in Ho Chi Minh City - who was also her translator Thursday.

"It's been in my mind for a long, long time," she said. "When I heard of the archive, I made up my mind I've got to come here."

What unit ambushed him?

Had he been betrayed by his own?

Did the U.S. military know who he was?

A week's worth of research has answered only the first of these questions.

Maxner and Minh Van located a report made by the ambushing party's commanders to their superiors. It's not the actual report written by the soldiers in the fight - they have yet to find that - but it shed some light on what led the gunboats and helicopters to the river crossing, which helps with the next two questions.

U.S. forces would regularly patrol areas of known river crossing at night, Maxner said. He said the ambush could have come during a routine patrol at time of day when anybody crossing the river was considered an enemy.

If the Americans had prior intelligence about the crossing that night, the command summaries would have mentioned it.

But there's no indication in the report that the Americans were waiting for them.

Also, Maxner added, if the U.S. intelligence had any inkling a man of Hoang Minh Dao's rank would be in the area, they would've sent a team to capture a prisoner, not kill combatants.

That, however, does not rule out the possibility of betrayal, Maxner said. The guide leading the party through the jungle could have been an American sympathizer who intentionally brought them into a known patrol route.

Again, though, this is only speculation.

She may not come away with all the answers on Saturday when she boards a flight to Florida on business, but Minh Van says she glad she looked here. And she plans to return next summer to look further.

Her life has turned out well, she said, with three married daughters and five grandchildren awaiting her back home.

The wounds have healed over the years, she said, and she long ago stopped being angry at the men who killed her father.

She has even visited the Vietnam War Veterans Memorial in Washington several times as an adult.

Every name and accompanying age etched in the wall makes for a potent reminder.

"Each time, I stare at the age of the soldiers and I'm asking myself why," she said. "Why did they go to such a faraway place to fight a war and die?"

Then, Minh Van said, she thinks of the families of all the names on the wall.

"They have the same questions," she added. "They have the same suffering."
